name: 03-Price-Elasticity-Calculation
parameters: --var getStarted=true --var selectRegion='UK' --var selectDistributor='Quality Goods Inc' --var selectRetailer='Rodriguez Ltd' --var selectSector='BCC' --var selectCategory='DIAPERS' --var selectSubCategory='Huggies' --var exploreData=true --var nextStage=true --var selectRetailer1='Rodriguez Ltd','Oconnor Glass','Jackson and Thompson Flores','Ryan and Green Lopez','Miller and Stevenson Green' --var selectSubCategory1='8H9FPQ','GZ0G57','X9YQ3T' --var letsExplore=true

nodes.name: PySpark
nodes.description: This node runs any given PySpark code. The input dataframe is passed into the function myfn as a parameter.

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: code
fields.value:
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession
from pyspark.sql import DataFrame
from pyspark.sql.functions import *
from fire.workflowcontext import WorkflowContext
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

def myfn(spark: SparkSession, workflowContext: WorkflowContext, id: int, inDF: DataFrame, cust_dict: dict):
    outDF = inDF  # add custom logic
    df = outDF.toPandas()

    def LinearModel(data):
        depvar = 'VOLUME_LOG'
        indpvar = ['PRICE_LOG']

        X = data[indpvar]
        y = data[depvar]

        model = LinearRegression()
        model.fit(X, y)

        return pd.Series({
            'RSquare': model.score(X, y),
            'Intercept': model.intercept_,
            'Price Elasticity': model.coef_[0],
            'DISP Elasticity': None
        })

    City_Wise_Price_Elasticity = df.groupby(['REGION']).apply(LinearModel).reset_index()
    City_Wise_Price_Elasticity.rename(columns={'Price Elasticity': 'City_Price_Elasticity', 'RSquare': 'City_RSquare','DISP Elasticity':'City_DISP_Elasticity'}, inplace=True)
    Spark_DF = spark.createDataFrame(City_Wise_Price_Elasticity)
    
    return Spark_DF
fields.title: PySpark
fields.description: PySpark code to be run. Input dataframe : "inDF", SparkContext : "sc", SQLContext : "sqlContext",  Output/Result dataframe should be registered as a temporary table - df.registerTempTable("outDF")

nodes.name: PySpark
nodes.description: This node runs any given PySpark code. The input dataframe is passed into the function myfn as a parameter.

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: code
fields.value:
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession
from pyspark.sql import DataFrame
from pyspark.sql.functions import *
from fire.workflowcontext import WorkflowContext
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

def myfn(spark: SparkSession, workflowContext: WorkflowContext, id: int, inDF: DataFrame, cust_dict: dict):
    outDF = inDF  # add custom logic
    df = outDF.toPandas()

    def LinearModel(data):
        depvar = 'VOLUME_LOG'
        indpvar = ['PRICE_LOG']

        X = data[indpvar]
        y = data[depvar]

        model = LinearRegression()
        model.fit(X, y)

        return pd.Series({
            'RSquare': model.score(X, y),
            'Intercept': model.intercept_,
            'Price Elasticity': model.coef_[0],
            'DISP Elasticity': model.coef_[1] if len(indpvar) > 1 else None
        })

    City_Wise_Price_Elasticity = df.groupby(['RETAILER', 'SKUID']).apply(LinearModel).reset_index()
    City_Wise_Price_Elasticity.rename(columns={'Price Elasticity': 'Retailer_Price_Elasticity', 'RSquare': 'Retailer_RSquare','DISP Elasticity':'Retailer_DISP_Elasticity'}, inplace=True)
    Spark_DF = spark.createDataFrame(City_Wise_Price_Elasticity)
    
    return Spark_DF

nodes.name: Print Rich Text
nodes.description: Displaying rich text

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: text
fields.value:
Summary﻿


  • The "Retailer_Price_Elasticity" represents the price elasticity of demand for each SKU at each retailer.
  • Price elasticity of demand measures the responsiveness of quantity demanded to changes in price. A higher absolute value of elasticity indicates greater sensitivity of demand to price changes.
  • Positive values indicate elastic demand, meaning that a percentage change in price leads to a greater percentage change in quantity demanded. Negative values indicate inelastic demand, where a percentage change in price leads to a smaller percentage change in quantity demanded.
  • For example, a SKU with a price elasticity of -2.2 implies that a 1% increase in price would lead to approximately a 2.2% decrease in the quantity demanded for that SKU.
fields.title: Text
fields.description: Displaying rich text
